channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Covid: Boris Johnson resisted autumn lockdown as only over-80s dying - Dominic Cummings
item.description: Boris Johnson also questioned whether the NHS would be overwhelmed, his former aide tells the BBC.

item.title: Covid: Two jabs needed to enter nightclubs from September
item.description: People will need to be fully vaccinated to enter venues where large crowds gather, the government says.

item.title: Covid: Isolation rules loosened for critical workers
item.description: People performing "critical" tasks including air traffic controllers will still be able to work under new rules.

item.title: Met Office issues first UK extreme heat warning
item.description: It covers south-west England and large parts of Wales as the UK experiences a prolonged hot spell.

item.title: Prince Harry promises to share 'highs and lows' in memoir
item.description: The book is due to be published next year and will be "accurate and wholly truthful", the prince says.

item.title: Covid is 'just the worst experience'
item.description: As most coronavrirus restrictions in England are lifted, Covid patients urge the public to take care.

item.title: January 6: First Capitol rioter sentenced to prison time
item.description: Paul Allard Hodgkins is the first of hundreds of Capitol rioters sentenced for a felony.

item.title: Germany floods: Government rejects criticism over flood warnings
item.description: As the flood risks ease, questions are raised whether the high death toll could have been avoided.

item.title: Zoom bets billions on home working continuing in Five9 deal
item.description: The firm announces a $14.7bn (£10.7bn) deal to buy Five9, a cloud-based call centre operator.

item.title: Ben & Jerry's to stop sales in Palestinian territories
item.description: The ice-cream maker said it was “inconsistent with our values” to continue selling products in the region.

item.title: Channel crossings: Fifty people land on Kent beach in single dinghy
item.description: A further eight boats carrying 241 migrants reached the UK on Sunday, the Home Office says.

item.title: Paralympian told to wear more appropriate shorts
item.description: Double world champion para-athlete Olivia Breen said she was left angry and speechless after being told to wear 'more appropriate' shorts.

item.title: Covid: What easing restrictions mean to people in a Witham estate
item.description: What does the lifting of restrictions in England mean to those living in a housing estate?

item.title: Horse racing: Inside the abattoir slaughtering racehorses
item.description: Campaign group Animal Aid set up covert cameras in one of the few slaughterhouses licensed to kill horses.

item.title: Shielders 'feeling abandoned' as coronavirus restrictions lifted
item.description: Three people who were told to shield during lockdown share their concerns as rules are eased in England.

item.title: NYPD officer uses crisp packet to save stabbing victim
item.description: The police officer in New York has been praised for his decisive actions.

item.title: Tips for staying cool by people from hot countries
item.description: BBC colleagues from Nigeria, Tanzania, Yemen and Brazil give us their advice for coping with hot weather.

item.title: Strictly Come Dancing: Greatest Dancer winner joins professional dancer line-up
item.description: Poland's Jowita Przystal is one of four new additions to the BBC One's team of professional dancers.

item.title: 19 July: The station where masks are mandatory - and not
item.description: Commuters at Farringdon station react to the varying face-covering rules now in place in London.

item.title: Frontline workers fearful as face mask rules ease
item.description: It is no longer a legal requirement to wear a face covering in England, but some employees are nervous.

item.title: Why I've hosted more than 30 refugees in my house
item.description: Karina Litvack has housed dozens of refugees in London since her daughters moved out.

item.title: Lex Gillette: Record-breaking blind long jumper
item.description: With the support of his sighted guide, the four-time Paralympic medallist hopes to win gold in Tokyo.

item.title: Covid: 'The shift to online has been life-changing'
item.description: Jase Puddicombe, 27, says the rise of digital services has improved access for disabled people.

item.title: Covid: What is the pilot testing scheme to avoid self-isolation?
item.description: The prime minister and chancellor were to participate in a trial to avoid self-isolation but then backtracked.

item.title: Olympics: Defying threats, Iranian athletes speak out to back ban
item.description: Olympics organisers are being urged to investigate allegations of threats, discrimination and abuse.

item.title: Hot weather: How to sleep in the heat
item.description: A simple guide on how to get a good night's sleep in the heat.

item.title: Horse racing: Thousands of racehorses killed in slaughterhouses
item.description: Some horses once trained by some of racing’s top names are being slaughtered, BBC Panorama finds.

item.title: Nightclubs reopen but fears remain for the industry's future
item.description: Figures given to Radio 1 Newsbeat show a quarter of clubs have closed in the past six years.

item.title: Covid: Is China's vaccine success waning in Asia?
item.description: Thailand and Indonesia's switch to other Covid jabs has raised questions about Chinese vaccines.

item.title: How to cool your home in a warming world
item.description: Low-energy designs and technologies can keep homes comfortable, come rain or shine.

item.title: Using plastic waste to help solve sand shortages
item.description: With construction sand in short supply crushed plastic is being used as an alternative.

item.title: Coronavirus doctor's diary: Unvaccinated patients with many regrets
item.description: The number of Covid patients in Bradford Royal Infirmary is rising sharply - and half are unvaccinated.

item.title: World Student Games: Sheffield's forgotten sporting spectacle
item.description: Sheffield's decision to host the World Student Games in 1991 still divides opinions across the city.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Tom Daley on triumph, trauma and his likely last shot at gold
item.description: The 'baby' of Beijing has become a father, a husband, an LGBTQ+ spokesperson. Tom Daley has perhaps one final shot at Olympic gold.

item.title: Nashville's Prokop becomes first active gay NHL player
item.description: Nashville Predators' Luke Prokop becomes the first active NHL player signed by a club to come out as gay.

item.title: Hamilton racially abused online after British Grand Prix victory
item.description: Lewis Hamilton is the target of racist abuse on social media after his victory in Sunday's British Grand Prix.

item.title: Arsenal sign Albert Sambi Lokonga from Anderlecht on long-term contract
item.description: Arsenal complete the signing of Anderlecht and Belgium youth midfielder Albert Sambi Lokonga on a long-term contract.

item.title: Grieving Biggar eyes Lions start against South Africa
item.description: Dan Biggar targets an "emotional" first British and Irish Lions Test start against South Africa after the recent death of his mother.

item.title: The Open 2021: Morikawa's bogey-free final round seals victory on Open debut
item.description: American debutant Collin Morikawa shoots a bogey-free final round to finish top of the Open leader board and claim the Claret Jug at Royal St George's.

item.title: Which children are being vaccinated and why?
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of children at higher risk from coronavirus infection will be offered a Covid vaccine in the UK.

item.title: Covid: Who has to self-isolate and what if I'm fully vaccinated?
item.description: Rules on self-isolation are being eased in England for children and fully vaccinated adults.

item.title: Covid rules from 19 July: What has changed?
item.description: Major changes to lockdown rules have taken effect in England and Scotland, but some restrictions remain.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: What are the rules and guidance for face masks and coverings from 19 July?
item.description: Masks are no longer compulsory in England, but remain necessary in Scotland and Wales.

item.title: What are the travel rules for Spain, Portugal, Malta and other holiday hotspots?
item.description: What you need to know about going to Portugal, Spain, Greece, France, Malta, Italy and Turkey.

item.title: Covid: Why is social distancing coming to an end?
item.description: Social distancing rules are changing across the UK.

item.title: 'Covid passports': How can the NHS Covid Pass prove I've had both jabs?
item.description: Clubbers and people attending mass events in England will have to prove they've had both Covid jabs.

item.title: Covid: What do over-18s need to know about the vaccine?
item.description: The vaccine rollout is now available for younger adults. What do they need to know about getting jabbed?

item.title: Covid-19: Five ways to avoid catching the virus indoors
item.description: As social distancing restrictions end in England and ease in Scotland, good ventilation remains vital.

item.title: Long Covid: What is it and what are the symptoms?
item.description: New research links as many as 200 different symptoms to the condition.

item.title: The EU vaccine 'passport' and what it means for travel
item.description: An EU vaccine "passport" is being introduced, enabling holders to prove they have been jabbed.

item.title: Coronavirus cure: What progress are we making on treatments?
item.description: Medical teams around the world are learning which medicines work best against Covid.

item.title: Esther Dingley: Partner vows to keep searching for missing hiker
item.description: The partner of missing hiker Esther Dingley explains why he won't give up searching for her.

item.title: Under the skin of OnlyFans
item.description: A BBC investigation reveals concerns about how the site, known for porn, is structured and moderated.

item.title: The Broadway dancer whose lockdown business bloomed
item.description: When Covid closed New York theatres, dancer Robbie Fairchild started a business that put down roots.

item.title: Olympic Games: 'Gang life nearly killed me - sprinting was my way out'
item.description: As Darren Campbell emerged as a talented teenage sprinter, he was leading a double life as a gang member. A twist of fate broke him free.

item.title: 'Indians don't talk about sex - so I help them'
item.description: An Indian sex coach says parents turn to her for advice as sex education is not available in schools.
